title: Front of the forearm, palm of the hand

questions.question: 1. Which muscle in the superficial layer of the anterior forearm is known for its frequent absence and is often used in tendon grafts?
2. Which muscle is primarily responsible for flexion of the wrist on the radial side of the forearm?
3. Which muscle of the anterior forearm is mainly supplied by the ulnar nerve?
4. Which deep muscle of the forearm is responsible for flexing the distal interphalangeal joints of the fingers?
5. The median nerve passes through which anatomical structure at the wrist?
6. What forms the roof of the carpal tunnel?
7. Which group of intrinsic hand muscles, innervated by the median nerve, is primarily responsible for thumb opposition?
options: Thenar muscles (opponens pollicis, abductor pollicis brevis, superficial head of flexor pollicis brevis)

questions.question: 8. Which artery primarily forms the superficial palmar arch in the hand?
9. Which intrinsic muscle of the hand is mainly responsible for adduction of the thumb?
10. Which nerve provides sensory innervation to the lateral palm, including the thumb, index, middle, and radial half of the ring finger?
11. Which deep muscle of the forearm is primarily responsible for flexing the thumb?
12. What is the primary action of the flexor digitorum superficialis?
options: Flexion of the proximal interphalangeal joints
Flexion of the distal interphalangeal joints

questions.question: 13. Which nerve innervates the deep muscles of the anterior forearm, such as the flexor pollicis longus and the medial half of the flexor digitorum profundus?
14. Which structure separates the superficial and deep layers of the anterior forearm?
15. The recurrent branch of which nerve supplies the thenar muscles of the hand?
